q1.text: The sleep cycle always runs in fixed stages.

q2.text: Sleep cycles can be altered by external influences such as light and temperature.

q3.text: Slow-wave sleep is crucial for physical recovery.

q4.text: Everyone needs the same amount of sleep.

q5.text: A complete sleep cycle lasts about 60 minutes.

q7.text: Melatonin production is highest during REM sleep.

q8.text: We only dream during REM sleep.

q9.text: Our body temperature and heart rate drop during slow-wave sleep.

q10.text: It’s harmful to wake up during REM sleep.

q11.text: Slow-wave sleep is dominated by delta waves with frequencies below 4 Hz.

q12.text: Melatonin and Cortisol are primarily involved in regulating the sleep-wake cycle.

q13.text: Serotonin is the primary neurotransmitter responsible for REM sleep.

q14.text: Alpha waves play a role in the initial sleep onset.

q1.text: During a sleep study, a participant is observed to have a high level of alpha wave activity (8-12 Hz). What does this suggest about their current state of sleep?
choices: They are likely experiencing restorative processes.
They may be in a state of wakefulness or light sleep.
They are in a slow-wave sleep with minimal brain activity.
q1.correct_answer: They may be in a state of wakefulness or light sleep.

q2.text: A person's sleep was monitored. The result is plotted in the sleep graph seen below. What sleep stage does the yellow segment (marked with an arrow) represent?

q3.text: A person exhibits prolonged periods of slow-wave sleep during the first half of the night, with a gradual increase in REM duration towards the morning. What does this pattern most likely indicate about their sleep architecture?
choices: A typical and healthy sleep cycle progression.
An unusual dominance of slow-wave sleep throughout the night.
A lack of REM rebound, possibly due to prior sleep deprivation.
q3.correct_answer: A typical and healthy sleep cycle progression.

q4.text: If someone only gets about 5 hours of sleep per night, which sleep stages are most likely to be impacted?

q5.text: Which of the following is a correct sequence of sleep stages in one complete sleep cycle?
choices: Light sleep → Moderate sleep → REM → Slow-wave sleep
REM → Light sleep → Moderate sleep → Slow-wave sleep
Light sleep → Moderate sleep → Slow-wave sleep → REM
Slow-wave sleep → Moderate sleep → Light sleep → REM
q5.correct_answer: Light sleep → Moderate sleep → Slow-wave sleep → REM

q1.text: All black holes form in the same way.

q2.text: Black holes are the densest objects in the universe.

q3.text: Black holes can form if the core of a star collapses.

q4.text: If the core of a star collapses, it can either form a black hole or a neutron star.

q5.text: The reason for the core of a star collapsing is that it is depleted of energy (aka. fuel to burn).

q6.text: When the core of a star collapses, the result is always the formation of a black hole.

q7.text: Any type of star can form a black hole, if the core of the star collapses.

q8.text: The width of a star is the main factor influencing the mass of a black hole that results from the star’s death.

q9.text: The explosion of the outer shell of a star that happens due to its core collapsing is called a supernova.

q10.text: The sun has enough mass to form a black hole.

q11.text: When a beam of light crosses the event horizon of a black hole, it comes out on the opposite side.

q12.text: The process of two black holes merging can create gravitational waves that are measurable on Earth.

q13.text: Black holes can also form without the core of a star collapsing.

q14.text: The mass, spin, and electric charge of a black hole is determined when it forms and does not change throughout its lifetime.

q1.text: Which of the following scenarios is most likely to lead to the formation of a black hole?
choices: The core of a star that is the size of the sun runs out of fuel and its core collapses.
A supernova that is the result of two massive stars colliding.
The core of a planet (i.e., earth) runs out of fuel and collapses.
q1.correct_answer: A supernova that is the result of two massive stars colliding.

q2.text: What process releases the energy that balances the gravitational force of a star and avoids its collapse, as long as enough energy is being produced?

q3.text: Which collision of two objects can lead to the formation of a black hole?
choices: Two black holes collide with each other.
Two planets the size of Earth colliding with each other.
A star (e.g., the sun) colliding with a planet (e.g., earth).
q3.correct_answer: Two black holes collide with each other.

q4.text: Which of the following chemical elements are an important consideration in the formation process of black holes?

q5.text: What typically happens when a massive star is near the end of its lifecycle?
choices: The star dies and becomes a white dwarf.
The star burns heavier elements/fuels, such as helium, carbon or oxygen, leading to a supernova.
The mass of the star forms a planet.
q5.correct_answer: The star burns heavier elements/fuels, such as helium, carbon or oxygen, leading to a supernova.

q1.text: One may only complete the rows that they have started themselves.

q2.text: One may complete a row that the other person has started and thus win.

q3.text: It is allowed to block a row that the other person has started in order to avoid losing.

q4.text: One chooses the piece that they place themselves.

q5.text: One may position pieces anywhere on free spaces on the board.

q6.text: One may also form a quarto diagonally.

q10.text: The game board has an even number of squares.

q11.text: There are a total of ten possible rows to form a quarto on the field.

q12.text: One person plays the light pieces and one person plays the dark pieces.

q13.text: One should always complete the row that the other person has started.

q14.text: One may only form a quarto with their own rows.

q1.text: Select the piece that would form a quarto with the three pieces shown.

q2.text: Select the piece that would form a quarto with the three pieces shown.

q3.text: Choose a piece which you would give to the other person for the next move.

q4.text: The following game situation is given. You are given the marked piece (small, square, light-colored, without a hole) by the other person. Where would you place the piece?

q5.text: The following game situation is given. Which piece would you give to the other person?
